qas.question: What name did Armenia gain it's name from?
What language does Armenias resemble most?

context: The exonym Armenia is attested in the Old Persian Behistun Inscription (515 BC) as Armina (    ). The ancient Greek terms Ἀρμενία (Armenía) and Ἀρμένιοι (Arménioi, "Armenians") are first mentioned by <a2_0>Hecataeus of Miletus<a2_0/> (c. 550 BC – c. 476 BC). Xenophon, a Greek general serving in some of the Persian expeditions, describes many aspects of Armenian village life and hospitality in around <a1_0>401 BC<a1_0/>. He relates that the people spoke a language that to his ear sounded like the language of the <a3_0>Persians<a3_0/>. According to the histories of both Moses of Chorene and Michael Chamchian, Armenia derives from the name of <a0_0>Aram<a0_0/>, a lineal descendant of Hayk.
